results.title: The Quiet Earth
results.creator_credit: Skouras Pictures, Sam Pillsbury, Don Reynolds and Geoff Murphy
results.brief_description: Bruno Lawrence plays a scientist who wakes up one morning to find that an experiment has gone dreadfully wrong and all living things seem to have disappeared from the planet. He searches for other living humans trying to fight off approaching madness and despair. He eventually meets up with two other survivors but as they realise the consequences of the science experiment on the Universe, their relationships fall apart. A haunting and provocative science-fiction film. Based on the novel by Craig Harrison.

results.title: The Quiet American (2001)
results.creator_credit: Intermedia, Mirage Enterprises, IMF (DE), William Horberg, Steffan Ahrenberg and Phil Noyce
results.brief_description: Thomas Fowler (Michael Caine) is an embittered British Journalist working in Vietnam (then Indochina), covering the political situation. A man known for his professional objectivity and honesty, Fowler’s personal life is a fiasco. Involved with a local woman, Phuong (Do Thi Hai Yen), whom he loves, Fowler is married to a strictly religious woman back in England who refuses to divorce him. Into their lives steps an enigmatic American man (Brendan Fraser). The American man falls for Phuong, and asks only that Phuong be given the opportunity to choose between the men and (like Indochina), resolve her destiny. In danger of losing Phuong to the American, Fowler is drawn into a suspicious and venomous state, convinced that the American is supplying explosives to non-Communist troops. “The Quiet American” leaves the more contentious political elements of Graham Greene’s novel to languish in favour of highlighting the personal grief of a middle-aged man in crisis. This version directed by Phillip Noyce is a remake of the 1958 film directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. Filmed on location in Vietnam and Fox Studios, Sydney.

results.title: The Quiet American
results.creator_credit: Figaro Films and Joseph L Mankiewicz
results.brief_description: Thomas Fowler (Michael Redgrave) is an embittered British journalist working in Vietnam (then Indochina), covering the political situation. A man known for his professional objectivity and honesty, Fowler’s personal life is a fiasco. Involved with a local woman, Phuong, whom he loves, Fowler is married to a strictly religious woman back in England who refuses to divorce him. Into their lives steps an enigmatic American man who hopes to rally the people of Indochina to become a third force and challenge the factions that seek to over-determine their lives. The American man falls for Phuong, and asks only that Phuong be given the opportunity to choose between the men and (like Indochina), resolve her destiny. In danger of losing Phuong to the American, Fowler is drawn into a suspicious and venomous state, convinced that the American is supplying explosives to non-Communist troops. “The Quiet American” leaves the more contentious political elements of Graham Greene’s novel to languish in favour of highlighting the personal grief of a middle-aged man in crisis. Redgrave is impressive as Fowler, whose voice-over narration relays comprehension of his fate, and his disastrous attempt to fight it. Remade in 2002 by Phillip Noyce.

results.title: The Quick and the dead
results.creator_credit: Tri-Star Pictures, Joshua Donin, Allen Shapiro, Patrick Markey and Sam Raimi
results.brief_description: Ellen (Sharon Stone), a female gunslinger, arrives in the town of Redemption for a quick-draw contest. The contest has been the initiative of the town’s corrupt mayor, Herod (Gene Hackman), and attracts gunslingers from around the county, all with mysterious pasts. Ellen is seeking revenge on Herod for past injustices, the smooth talker known as ‘The Kid’ (Leonardo DiCaprio) may possibly be the mayor’s son, and the quiet Reverend Cort (Russell Crowe) refuses to participate despite being the fastest gun in town. As the contest continues all is revealed, leading to a final showdown between Ellen and Herod.

results.title: The Quare fellow
results.creator_credit: BLC, Bryanston Films, Anthony Havelock-Allan and Arthur Dreifuss
results.brief_description: A condemned killer awaits his execution. A funny tragedy, a happy- go-lucky horror show, a gay little wake for the dead who have died in the name of justice - the kind of justice that demands a life for a life. Like Brendan Behan’s play, the picture ignores the rational arguments against capital punishment. It simply takes the audience inside an Irish prison and bolts the gate, and then with a world of Irish charm and humour shows everybody how it feels to live in a cell - and die on a rope.

results.title: The Purple rose of Cairo
results.creator_credit: Jack Rollins, Charles H. Joffe, Robert Greenhut and Woody Allen
results.brief_description: Trapped in a dreary marriage, Cecilia escapes to the cinema and in particular to the romantic adventure “The purple rose of Cairo”. Then one night as she watches the film the hero, Tom Baxter, steps out of the screen and into her life. But where does that leave the other characters - indeed the whole film? The real-life actor who played Tom is in danger of his career being finished, the producers see only lawsuits coming their way. Pandemonium sets in as real life clashes with fantasy. A bitter-sweet comedy starring Mia Farrow, Jeff Daniels and Danny Aiello. Best film 1985 British Academy Awards.

results.title: The Purple plain
results.creator_credit: Rank Organisation Film Productions, Two Cities Films, John Bryan and Robert Parrish
results.brief_description: This psychological wartime drama set in Burma was based on the novel by H.E. Bates. A Canadian pilot (Gregory Peck) and two comrades-in-arms crash in the Burmese wilds. The three men are forced to hack their way through the jungle to safety, surrounded on all sides by the Japanese. The pilot’s subordinates don’t completely trust their leader, and not without reason - his nerves have been at breaking point for months. Faced with this severe test of courage and endurance, he must muster the physical and mental resources to lead his men to safety. Cast includes Maurice Denham, Win Min Than, Lyndon Brook, Anthony Bushell and Josephone Griffin.

results.title: The Public enemy
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures and William Wellman
results.brief_description: James Cagney plays Tom Powers, the son of a Chicago policeman, growing up in the city slums where, as a boy, he naturally turns to petty crime as a way of life. As an adult he becomes a successful big-time liquor racketeer. Tom Power has no socially redeemimg traits. He takes pleasure in even the most petty of physical insults, such as grinding half a grapefruit into the startled face of Mae Clark. Cagney’s raw ferocious portrayal of a vicious criminal is masterful and the film is a classic in its genre. Also stars Jean Harlow and Joan Blondell.

results.title: The Producers
results.creator_credit: Springtime, Crossbow, Sidney Glazier and Mel Brooks
results.brief_description: Considered one of Mel Brook’s funniest films, this hilarious farce follows an attempted swindle by a con artist (Zero Mostel) and his accountant (Gene Wilder) who attempt to stage a Broadway flop only to have it backfire. This film has achieved cult status and is known for musical interlude “Springtime for Hitler”. Wilder received an Oscar nomination for his role in this zany classic. The phony play was later actually produced by Alan Johnson.

results.title: The Private life of Henry VIII = The Private life of Henry Eighth
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, Alexander Korda and Ludovico Toeplitz
results.brief_description: Charles Laughton won an Academy Award for his portrayal of Henry VIII in this film directed and co-produced by Alexander Korda. As the title suggests, the narrative plots the private life of Henry VIII - six marriages and numerous affairs for a hedonistic creature given to excess in all areas of life. Laughton plays Henry as an exuberant, gargantuan man with a lusty libido and appetite but little regard for the lives of others. The film is largely comedic in tone but does address some of Henry’s political struggles and ambitions for England. Period detail and lavish costumes set the 16th century scene, even if the dialogue has a more modern tone. Cast includes: Merle Oberon, Wendy Barrie, Elsa Lanchester, Binnie Barnes, Robert Donnat and Everly Gregg. Despite not winning the Academy Award for Best Picture, the success of “The Private life of Henry VIII” put British cinema on the map, which was from then on regarded as a real threat to Hollywood domination of the market.
